body: This adds a command for the additional `julials` API for activating an environment. This is based on how extra functionality is added into the `texlab` configuration

comment_data.body:
You can first check whether
```lua
if not julia_client then
      return vim.notify
end
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,5 +1,34 @@
 local util = require 'lspconfig.util'
 
+local function activate_env()
+  local bufnr = vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf()
+  local julials_client = util.get_active_client_by_name(bufnr, 'julials')
+  if julials_client then
+    local julia_project_files = { 'Project.toml', 'JuliaProject.toml' }
+    local depot_envs = vim.fs.normalize(vim.env.JULIA_DEPOT_PATH or vim.fn.expand '~/.julia') .. '/environments'
+    local environments = {}
+    vim.list_extend(environments, vim.fs.find(julia_project_files, { type = 'file', upward = true, limit = math.huge }))
+    vim.list_extend(
+      environments,
+      vim.fs.find(function(name, path)
+        return vim.tbl_contains(julia_project_files, name) and string.sub(path, #depot_envs + 1):match '^/[^/]*$'
+      end, { path = depot_envs, type = 'file', limit = math.huge })
+    )
+    environments = vim.tbl_map(util.path.dirname, environments)
+    vim.ui.select(environments, { prompt = 'Select a Julia environment' }, function(environment)
+      if environment then
+        julials_client.notify('julia/activateenvironment', { envPath = environment })
+        vim.notify('Julia environment activated: \n`' .. environment .. '`', vim.log.levels.INFO)
+      end
+    end)
+  else
+    vim.notify(
+      'method julia/activateenvironment is not supported by any servers active on the current buffer',
+      vim.log.levels.WARN
+    )
+  end
+end

comment_data.body: Revised the commit to follow this pattern. Thanks for the suggestion

comment_data.body: This kind of stuff (reading env var JULIA_DEPOT_PATH) is a bad sign. How are users going to know about that? That's a hidden assumption in the impl of this command. Should be documented at least, in the `docs` field below.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,5 +1,34 @@
 local util = require 'lspconfig.util'
 
+local function activate_env()
+  local bufnr = vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf()
+  local julials_client = util.get_active_client_by_name(bufnr, 'julials')
+  if not julials_client then
+    vim.notify(
+      'method julia/activateenvironment is not supported by any servers active on the current buffer',
+      vim.log.levels.WARN
+    )
+    return
+  end

+  local depot_envs = vim.fs.normalize(vim.env.JULIA_DEPOT_PATH or vim.fn.expand '~/.julia') .. '/environments'

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
      activate_env
```

Ok, I can document it in the description. The environment variable `JULIA_DEPOT_PATH` is a special environment variable dictated by the programming language itself.

https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/environment-variables/#JULIA_DEPOT_PATH

comment_data.body:
Yes, but when would `julials_client` ever be undefined? Commands defined in `commands` (I think?) are not defined unless their associated config is active for a buffer.

If that's correct, then only an `assert` should be needed since this is an unexpected situation.

comment_data.body: It might be a good idea to keep the 0.9 support for now simply because the debian packages are currently at 0.9 so it would be good to have such a core plugin support the versions that are widely available. Moving forward it could be a good idea to make some sort of development practice such as "will support the latest 2 Neovim stable releases at all time or something just so people have an idea what is valid and enable a bit more stability in configuration management, but this is a separate discussion

comment_data.body:
Is ":" the path separator that Julia uses on Windows?

This is why I'm so reluctant to merge these non-trivial command wrappers. They hide numerous subtle decisions that lead to bug reports later.

And it looks like the amount of code doubled in the last hour. (It's good to be robust, but also need to find ways to re-use code)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,5 +1,54 @@
 local util = require 'lspconfig.util'
 
+local function activate_env(path)
+  local bufnr = vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf()
+  local julials_clients = util.get_lsp_clients { bufnr = bufnr, name = 'julials' }
+  assert(
+    #julials_clients > 0,
+    'method julia/activateenvironment is not supported by any servers active on the current buffer'
+  )
+  local julia_project_files = { 'Project.toml', 'JuliaProject.toml' }
+  local function _activate_env(environment)
+    if environment then
+      for _, julials_client in ipairs(julials_clients) do
+        julials_client.notify('julia/activateenvironment', { envPath = environment })
+      end
+      vim.notify('Julia environment activated: \n`' .. environment .. '`', vim.log.levels.INFO)
+    end
+  end
+  if path then
+    path = vim.fs.normalize(path)
+    local found_env = false
+    for _, project_file in ipairs(julia_project_files) do
+      if util.path.exists(util.path.join(path, project_file)) then
+        found_env = true
+        break
+      end
+    end
+    if not found_env then
+      vim.notify('Path is not a julia environment: \n`' .. path .. '`', vim.log.levels.WARN)
+      return
+    end
+    _activate_env(path)
+  else
+    local depot_paths = vim.env.JULIA_DEPOT_PATH and vim.split(vim.env.JULIA_DEPOT_PATH, ':')

comment_data.body: Use `vim.fs.joinpath`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,5 +1,54 @@
 local util = require 'lspconfig.util'
 
+local function activate_env(path)
+  local bufnr = vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf()
+  local julials_clients = util.get_lsp_clients { bufnr = bufnr, name = 'julials' }
+  assert(
+    #julials_clients > 0,
+    'method julia/activateenvironment is not supported by any servers active on the current buffer'
+  )
+  local julia_project_files = { 'Project.toml', 'JuliaProject.toml' }
+  local function _activate_env(environment)
+    if environment then
+      for _, julials_client in ipairs(julials_clients) do
+        julials_client.notify('julia/activateenvironment', { envPath = environment })
+      end
+      vim.notify('Julia environment activated: \n`' .. environment .. '`', vim.log.levels.INFO)
+    end
+  end
+  if path then
+    path = vim.fs.normalize(path)
+    local found_env = false
+    for _, project_file in ipairs(julia_project_files) do
+      if util.path.exists(util.path.join(path, project_file)) then
+        found_env = true
+        break
+      end
+    end
+    if not found_env then
+      vim.notify('Path is not a julia environment: \n`' .. path .. '`', vim.log.levels.WARN)
+      return
+    end
+    _activate_env(path)
+  else
+    local depot_paths = vim.env.JULIA_DEPOT_PATH and vim.split(vim.env.JULIA_DEPOT_PATH, ':')
+      or { vim.fn.expand '~/.julia' }
+    local environments = {}
+    vim.list_extend(environments, vim.fs.find(julia_project_files, { type = 'file', upward = true, limit = math.huge }))
+    for _, depot_path in ipairs(depot_paths) do
+      local depot_env = util.path.join(vim.fs.normalize(depot_path), 'environments')

comment_data.body: Ah, I misunderstood the previous discussion. I thought it should still use the `get_clients` utility since the rest of the codebase supports neovim 0.9 and then the 0.9 support would be dropped in a later PR

comment_data.body:
> Irrelevant for this PR. `vim.lsp.get_clients()` exists in 0.9

I figured adding code that doesn't not match the current Neovim version support of the plugin would be irrelevant for this PR and a followup would make the blanket decision of which Neovim version to support. For now, I have removed the 0.9 support as requested

comment_data.body: @justinmk is this `assert` correct? It seems like if the language server is stopped for any reason then this command doesn't automatically delete itself so it's not really an assertion and should probably just be a nice notification check. The command existing only means that the language server has been attached to the buffer previously. I think this is probably why the other similar commands in `nvim-lspconfig` do a notification rather than an assertion
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,5 +1,34 @@
 local util = require 'lspconfig.util'
 
+local function activate_env()
+  local bufnr = vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf()
+  local julials_client = util.get_active_client_by_name(bufnr, 'julials')
+  if not julials_client then
+    vim.notify(
+      'method julia/activateenvironment is not supported by any servers active on the current buffer',
+      vim.log.levels.WARN

comment_data.body: I am going to go ahead and revert the use of `assert` because the original comment regarding the commands only being available when the language server is active is incorrect. I can revise it back to an `assert` if this is desired.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,5 +1,34 @@
 local util = require 'lspconfig.util'
 
+local function activate_env()
+  local bufnr = vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf()
+  local julials_client = util.get_active_client_by_name(bufnr, 'julials')
+  if not julials_client then
+    vim.notify(
+      'method julia/activateenvironment is not supported by any servers active on the current buffer',
+      vim.log.levels.WARN

comment_data.body: can this loop be replaced by `vim.fs.find` ? Nvim versions before 0.10 are not supported (especially for commands)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,5 +1,59 @@
 local util = require 'lspconfig.util'
 
+local function activate_env(path)
+  local bufnr = vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf()
+  local julials_clients = (vim.lsp.get_clients or vim.lsp.get_active_clients) { bufnr = bufnr, name = 'julials' }
+  if #julials_clients == 0 then
+    vim.notify(
+      'method julia/activateenvironment is not supported by any servers active on the current buffer',
+      vim.log.levels.WARN
+    )
+    return
+  end
+  local julia_project_files = { 'Project.toml', 'JuliaProject.toml' }
+  local function _activate_env(environment)
+    if environment then
+      for _, julials_client in ipairs(julials_clients) do
+        julials_client.notify('julia/activateenvironment', { envPath = environment })
+      end
+      vim.notify('Julia environment activated: \n`' .. environment .. '`', vim.log.levels.INFO)
+    end
+  end
+  if path then
+    path = vim.fs.normalize(path)
+    local found_env = false
+    for _, project_file in ipairs(julia_project_files) do
+      local file = (vim.uv or vim.loop).fs_stat(vim.fs.joinpath(path, project_file))
+      if file and file.type then
+        found_env = true
+        break
+      end
+    end

comment_data.body:
there is no reason that commands need to support older Nvim versions.

```suggestion
local function activate_env(path)
  assert(vim.fn.has('nvim-0.10') == 1, 'requires Nvim 0.10 or newer')
```

then, remove the `vim.loop` usages below, `get_active_clients`, and any other outdated apis.

+local function activate_env(path)

comment_data.body: an assert() is sufficient.

comment_data.body: I don't think so because `vim.fs.find` doesn't have a maximum depth. It has a `stop` parameter which stops when a given directory is reached but this really is only applicable doing an upwards search and there is no way to limit the depth it searches. Here we need to find project files just inside the directory that is passed in and not looking for them infinitely recursing down.

comment_regular_data.body: Looks like this fails the CI/CD check regarding the use of `dirname` and it potentially being used in the `root_dir`. I'm just confirming that the use of `dirname` does not go against the directive listed in the CI/CD check :)

title: feat(julials): add `JuliaActivateEnv` to activate a julia environment
